triples.name: Large language model
triples.relevance: LLMs are the core technology used to enable ProAgent's adaptive behavior and reasoning capabilities in multi-agent cooperation.

triples.name: Multi-agent system
triples.relevance: The paper addresses the fundamental problem of building cooperative agents within multi-agent systems.

triples.name: Zero-shot learning
triples.relevance: Zero-shot coordination is the key challenge that ProAgent tackles, enabling agents to cooperate with unfamiliar teammates without prior training.

triples.name: Self-play
triples.relevance: Self-play is a baseline training method that ProAgent outperforms in experimental evaluations on cooperative tasks.

triples.name: Population-based incremental learning
triples.relevance: Population-based training is a competing method that ProAgent demonstrates superior performance against in cooperative agent experiments.

triples.name: Cooperative game theory
triples.relevance: Cooperative game theory provides the theoretical foundation for understanding cooperative behavior in multi-agent systems.

triples.name: Theory of mind
triples.relevance: The ability to infer teammates' intentions and update beliefs about their behavior is related to theory of mind capabilities.

triples.name: Activity recognition
triples.relevance: ProAgent's capability to analyze state and infer teammate intentions relates to activity and behavior recognition.

triples.name: Reinforcement learning
triples.relevance: Reinforcement learning is the underlying paradigm for training cooperative agents that ProAgent builds upon and improves.

triples.name: Natural language processing
triples.relevance: ProAgent proposes a novel application of NLP and LLM reasoning for inferring teammate intentions and adapting agent behavior in coordination tasks.
